articles.headline: Merck Says It Has the First Antiviral Pill Found to Be Effective Against Covid
articles.snippet: The drug maker will seek authorization for molnupiravir, the first drug of its kind for Covid. Experts said such pills could be a powerful tool against the virus.
articles.abstract: The drug maker will seek authorization for molnupiravir, the first drug of its kind for Covid. Experts said such pills could be a powerful tool against the virus.
articles.lead_paragraph: The drug maker Merck said on Friday that its pill to treat Covid-19 was shown in a key clinical trial to halve the risk of hospitalization or death when given to high-risk people early in their infections.
articles.byline: By Rebecca Robbins

articles.headline: Ozy Media, Once a Darling of Investors, Shuts Down in a Swift Unraveling
articles.snippet: The digital media start-up had come under scrutiny for its business practices after articles in The Times.
articles.abstract: The digital media start-up had come under scrutiny for its business practices after articles in The Times.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ozy Media, the digital media company that came under intense scrutiny for its business practices in recent days, announced on Friday that it was shutting down, following a sudden flight of investors and advertisers and bringing to a close a strange chapter in the annals of online journalism.
articles.byline: By Ben Smith and Katie Robertson

articles.headline: Facebook Struggles to Quell Uproar Over Instagram’s Effect on Teens
articles.snippet: The social network has been all hands on deck as it grapples with revelations that it knew the harmful effects its Instagram photo-sharing app was having on teenagers.
articles.abstract: The social network has been all hands on deck as it grapples with revelations that it knew the harmful effects its Instagram photo-sharing app was having on teenagers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the past few weeks, top Facebook executives assembled virtually for a series of emergency meetings.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac, Sheera Frenkel and Ryan Mac

articles.headline: Biden Pulls Back on Infrastructure Bill, Tying It to Social Policy Measure
articles.snippet: After pressing toward a vote, Democratic leaders accepted “reality” that the bill could not pass before a broad climate change and safety net measure comes together.
articles.abstract: After pressing toward a vote, Democratic leaders accepted “reality” that the bill could not pass before a broad climate change and safety net measure comes together.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden, facing an intraparty battle over his domestic agenda, put his own $1 trillion infrastructure bill on hold on Friday, telling Democrats that a vote on the popular measure must wait until Democrats pass his far more ambitious social policy and climate change package.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: They Want to Hand Your Kid a Debit Card. What Do You Do?
articles.snippet: Start-ups large and small are offering child-friendly debit cards that allow parents to set up guardrails. Picking one depends on your priorities.
articles.abstract: Start-ups large and small are offering child-friendly debit cards that allow parents to set up guardrails. Picking one depends on your priorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Introducing your child to the real-world use of money often means hacking together half-baked solutions: jars stuffed with bills combined with repeated trips to the A.T.M. and teenage misuse of the parental credit card.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber

articles.headline: An Erotica Pioneer Goes From Hero to Villain for Dozens of Authors
articles.snippet: In the constantly evolving romance landscape, Blushing Books has long occupied a specific niche: spanking erotica. Now some of its most successful writers just want their books back.
articles.abstract: In the constantly evolving romance landscape, Blushing Books has long occupied a specific niche: spanking erotica. Now some of its most successful writers just want their books back.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anne Wills was a mother of four who doted on her children, was an active volunteer with a youth swim team, loved animals and was known to those around her as a generous, nurturing, motherly figure in her small town in rural Virginia.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Alter

articles.headline: Perilous, Roadless Jungle Becomes a Path of Desperate Hope
articles.snippet: The recent surge at the Mexican border is likely to grow as more migrants, mostly Haitian, risk everything negotiating the notorious Darién Gap on their way to the United States.
articles.abstract: The recent surge at the Mexican border is likely to grow as more migrants, mostly Haitian, risk everything negotiating the notorious Darién Gap on their way to the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: NECOCLÍ, Colombia — For decades, the Darién Gap, a roadless, lawless stretch of jungle linking South America to the north, was considered so dangerous that only a few thousand people a year were daring, or desperate, enough to try to cross it.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz, Natalie Kitroeff, Sofía Villamil and Federico Rios

articles.headline: Subduing Suspects Face Down Isn’t Fatal, Research Has Said. Now the Research Is on Trial.
articles.snippet: For years, the leading experts have testified that prone restraint by police is safe. So why do people keep dying?
articles.abstract: For years, the leading experts have testified that prone restraint by police is safe. So why do people keep dying?
articles.lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, Md. — It was a warm Saturday evening when Jennell Black heard a commotion outside her mobile home on Maryland’s Eastern Shore. Outside her door, four men were holding her 19-year-old son face down, pinning his shoulder, legs and arms. One of them, who turned out to be an off-duty police chief from a nearby town, was lying on top of him.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan

articles.headline: Inside United Airlines’ Decision to Mandate Coronavirus Vaccines
articles.snippet: Over the course of a year, the company and its unions grappled with when and how to require vaccination for its 67,000 U.S. employees.
articles.abstract: Over the course of a year, the company and its unions grappled with when and how to require vaccination for its 67,000 U.S. employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Scott Kirby, the chief executive of United Airlines, reached a breaking point while vacationing in Croatia this summer: After receiving word that a 57-year-old United pilot had died after contracting the coronavirus, he felt it was time to require all employees to get vaccinated.
articles.byline: By Niraj Chokshi and Noam Scheiber

articles.headline: Biden Throws In With Left, Leaving His Agenda in Doubt
articles.snippet: Progressives flexed, but remain empty-handed. Moderates feel betrayed. The outcome of their battle could determine Democrats’ fate in the midterms and the success of the Biden presidency.
articles.abstract: Progressives flexed, but remain empty-handed. Moderates feel betrayed. The outcome of their battle could determine Democrats’ fate in the midterms and the success of the Biden presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For well over a year now, President Biden’s vaunted negotiating style largely boiled down to this: I’m with you.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: The Lawyer Behind the Memo on How Trump Could Stay in Office
articles.snippet: John Eastman was a little-known but respected conservative lawyer. Then he became influential with Donald Trump — and counseled him on how to retain power after losing the election.
articles.abstract: John Eastman was a little-known but respected conservative lawyer. Then he became influential with Donald Trump — and counseled him on how to retain power after losing the election.
articles.lead_paragraph: John Eastman’s path from little-known academic to one of the most influential voices in Donald J. Trump’s ear in the final days of his presidency began in mid-2019 on Mr. Trump’s favorite platform: television.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Back on the Bench, the Supreme Court Faces a Blockbuster Term
articles.snippet: The court, which is dominated by six Republican appointees, will confront a charged docket, including a case asking it to overrule Roe v. Wade.
articles.abstract: The court, which is dominated by six Republican appointees, will confront a charged docket, including a case asking it to overrule Roe v. Wade.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A transformed Supreme Court returns to the bench on Monday to start a momentous term in which it will consider eliminating the constitutional right to abortion, vastly expanding gun rights and further chipping away at the wall separating church and state.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak

articles.headline: In Alaska’s Covid Crisis, Doctors Must Decide Who Lives and Who Dies
articles.snippet: Amid the nation’s worst Covid-19 outbreak, patients are trapped in remote communities and doctors are prioritizing treatment based on who is most likely to survive.
articles.abstract: Amid the nation’s worst Covid-19 outbreak, patients are trapped in remote communities and doctors are prioritizing treatment based on who is most likely to survive.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Mike Baker

articles.headline: Skateboards, Climate Change and Freedom: Germany’s Next-Generation Parliament
articles.snippet: A new generation of lawmakers is entering Germany’s Parliament. They felt ignored by the previous government, so they set out to change that by winning elections.
articles.abstract: A new generation of lawmakers is entering Germany’s Parliament. They felt ignored by the previous government, so they set out to change that by winning elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Emilia Fester is 23 and has yet to finish college. Max Lucks is 24 and calls himself a militant cyclist. Ria Schröder is 29 and has the rainbow flag on her Twitter profile. Muhanad Al-Halak is 31 and came to Germany from Iraq when he was 11.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: Vietnamese Americans, Once Displaced Themselves, Mobilize to Help Afghans
articles.snippet: For many who made it to the United States, watching the chaotic exit from Afghanistan evoked memories of their own harrowing experiences.
articles.abstract: For many who made it to the United States, watching the chaotic exit from Afghanistan evoked memories of their own harrowing experiences.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the middle of the night, Uyen Nguyen trudged through a grassy marshland with her mother and three siblings until they reached the edge of the ocean, where a small, dilapidated fishing boat was beached on the sand. It set off with 31 people packed on it.
articles.byline: By Madeleine Ngo

articles.headline: What They Saw in Ozy
articles.snippet: The story behind the story is about the elite investors who plowed millions into a media dream without much due diligence, persuaded by the charm of Ozy’s head, Carlos Watson.
articles.abstract: The story behind the story is about the elite investors who plowed millions into a media dream without much due diligence, persuaded by the charm of Ozy’s head, Carlos Watson.
articles.lead_paragraph: There’s an irresistible temptation, in this age of scams and hype, to obsess about the man or woman at the center of a company’s implosion. Theranos’s Elizabeth Holmes was the subject of an HBO documentary, and is now the center of a high-profile trial. And when Ozy Media collapsed on Friday, less than a week after The New York Times reported on a series of misleading statements and actions, all eyes turned to the man at the center of the company, Carlos Watson, an ambitious dreamer who seemed to believe in what he was selling. When he spoke with me over Zoom from a California backyard on Sunday, he conceded nothing.
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: Whistle-Blower Says Facebook ‘Chooses Profits Over Safety’
articles.snippet: Frances Haugen, a Facebook product manager who left the company in May, revealed that she had provided internal documents to journalists and others.
articles.abstract: Frances Haugen, a Facebook product manager who left the company in May, revealed that she had provided internal documents to journalists and others.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: The Stock Market’s Hot Summer Became a Swoon. Where Does It Go Next?
articles.snippet: Inflation and supply chain problems have been a concern since the pandemic began. But action by the Federal Reserve and pressure on corporate profits put those worries in sharp focus.
articles.abstract: Inflation and supply chain problems have been a concern since the pandemic began. But action by the Federal Reserve and pressure on corporate profits put those worries in sharp focus.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just four weeks ago, the stock market looked unstoppable. Seven straight months of gains had left the S&P 500 index up 21 percent for the year, corporations enjoyed record profits and economists predicted the fastest growth in decades.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips

articles.headline: Hungary’s Leader Fights Criticism in U.S. via Vast Influence Campaign
articles.snippet: Viktor Orban, the country’s far-right prime minister, has spent millions on lobbying, support for think tanks and cultivating allies in Washington.
articles.abstract: Viktor Orban, the country’s far-right prime minister, has spent millions on lobbying, support for think tanks and cultivating allies in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former Vice President Mike Pence turned up in Hungary last month to speak to a conference on conservative social values hosted by the far-right government of Prime Minister Viktor Orban.
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Benjamin Novak

articles.headline: Facebook Is Weaker Than We Knew
articles.snippet: A trove of leaked documents, published by The Wall Street Journal, hints at a company whose best days are behind it.
articles.abstract: A trove of leaked documents, published by The Wall Street Journal, hints at a company whose best days are behind it.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Kevin Roose

articles.headline: U.S. Signals No Thaw in Trade Relations With China
articles.snippet: The Biden administration said it would not immediately remove the Trump administration’s tariffs and would require that Beijing uphold its trade commitments.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration said it would not immediately remove the Trump administration’s tariffs and would require that Beijing uphold its trade commitments.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration offered its strongest signal yet that the United States’ combative economic approach toward China would continue, with senior administration officials saying that President Biden would not immediately lift tariffs on Chinese goods and that he would hold Beijing accountable for trade commitments agreed to during the Trump administration.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher
